info.game_comments:
2001 International Championship semifinal game 2.
  From the Las Vegas Hilton.

(1, 1).clue: In an 1870s ballet, Prince Siegfried falls in love with one of these graceful birds

(2, 1).clue: The storming of this prison in 1789 is one of the most famous events of the French Revolution

(4, 1).clue: Hepatitis & cirrhosis are diseases of this organ

(5, 1).clue: Oxford graduate Hugh Grant played a student at this other British university in the coming-of-age film "Maurice"

(6, 1).clue: Esperanto adverbs generally end in "E"; these words, like bela for "beautiful", in "A"

(1, 2).clue: This singer took "Oh, Pretty Woman" to No. 1 in 1964

(4, 2).clue: The tympanic membrane is another name for this body part

(3, 3).clue: Seen here, Manet's painting of "Nana" hangs in the Kunshalle, a great museum in this seaport of northern Germany

(4, 3).clue: When the intestine bulges into the groin muscles, it's the inguinal type of this

(3, 4).clue: We wonder what they sell in the gift shop of the Opium House Museum in Sop Ruak, this nation's Golden Triangle

(4, 4).clue: A deficiency of vitamin D is a common cause of this disease that causes bone deformities like bowed legs

(5, 4).clue: It's the official language of Bahrain

(6, 4).clue: Arbaro is this type of place as in Longfellow's "Jen la Arbaro Pratempa"

(1, 5).clue: In a Sir Walter Scott novel, this title character is an outlaw of the MacGregor clan

(4, 5).clue: Alexia is word blindness; this is a reading disability in which letters are reversed &/or transposed

(6, 5).clue: Originally the pseudonym of the language's creator, Esperanto means "one who" does this

(1, 1).clue: This 17-year-old Venetian left Venice in 1271 & met Kublai Khan 4 years later

(4, 1).clue: A point equidistant from the vertices of a regular polygon or a position in hockey & basketball
